metadata.case_name: S. Gangoli and P. R. Chaudhri v. The State

facts.text: Chaudhri (appellant No. 2) posted as Assistant Permanent Way Inspector, Sultanpur, East Indian Railway, Lucknow E.I.R. Division, in March 1948.
Gangoli (appellant No. 1) posted as Assistant Pay Clerk in Lucknow E.I.R. Division during the same period.
Sum of Rs. 16,685 entrusted to appellant No. 2 by railway department to be disbursed among Class IV staff working under appellant No. 1, in accordance with Pay Commission's Report.
Payment to be made in presence of and attested by appellant No. 1.
Appellants entered into criminal conspiracy to misappropriate part of amount by paying lesser amounts to Class IV staff and falsifying pay-sheets to show full payment.
Payment made on March 11, 1948, in running train between Faizabad and Chilbila; entries show Rs. 16,591 paid to 216 employees by appellant No. 2, attested by appellant No. 1.
Actual disbursement Rs. 1,555 less; appellants misappropriated Rs. 1,555.
Employees suspicious after learning others paid larger arrears; approached higher officers.
Employees presented written complaints; led to enquiry by Mr. Dalip Singh who recorded statements on April 6 and 7, 1948.
Appellant No. 1 called employees together and paid previously deducted amounts; three documents executed: Exs. 5, 10 and 11.
Appellants denied charges; no conspiracy; falsely implicated. Appellant 1: due to enmity with H.N. Das aided by Shambu. Appellant 2: refused to implicate appellant 1.
Prosecution examined 44 witnesses, relied on Exs. 5, 10, 11.
Sessions Judge, Lucknow, convicted appellants agreeing with assessors: appellant 1 RI 3 years, appellant 2 RI 2 years under s.120B IPC and s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(c),(d) PCA.
Appeals to High Court of Judicature at Allahabad dismissed; Justice Kidwai partly accepted defence on some witnesses but confirmed conviction based on gangmen evidence and Exs. 5,11.
East Indian Railway owned by Government of India at material time.

legal_issues.text: Are the appellants public servants under s. 2 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947?

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants are not public servants under s.2 PCA because s.137(4) Railways Act provides that railway servants shall not be deemed public servants for purposes of IPC except ch.IX; offences not under ch.IX IPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.137(4) Indian Railways Act 1890; s.21 IPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution evidence interested, false; documents fabricated or irrelevant.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants committed offences under s.120B IPC and s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(c),(d) PCA; evidence of 44 witnesses and Exs.5,10,11 prove charges.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Prevention of Corruption Act 1947 ss.5(1)(c),5(1)(d),5(2); IPC s.120B

court_reasoning.text: S.2 PCA incorporates definition of public servant from s.21 IPC; appellants are public servants under s.21 IPC as employed by Govt-owned railway.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.137(4) Railways Act bars treating railway servants as public servants only for purposes of IPC outside ch.IX; does not apply to offences under PCA.

court_reasoning.text: S.137(1) deems railway servants public servants for ch.IX IPC; s.137(4) confines bar to IPC purposes; PCA offences outside IPC, so s.21 IPC applies directly via s.2 PCA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bar in s.137(4) not extended to offences outside Penal Code.

court_reasoning.text: Devi Ram (Punj HC) obiter and based on misconstruction; Ram Krishan and Montorio support appellants as public servants under PCA pre-1955 amendment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prior SC decisions treat railway servants as public servants under PCA.

court_reasoning.text: No justification to reduce sentence; positions, method of offence considered by lower courts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amount misappropriated not decisive for sentence.

holdings.text: Railway servants employed by Government-owned railway are public servants under s.2 PCA via s.21 IPC; s.137(4) Railways Act inapplicable to PCA offences.

precedents_cited.case_name: Devi Ram Deep Chand v. The State
precedents_cited.relevance: Held obiter and based on misconstruction of s.137(4); railway servants not public servants under s.21 IPC for PCA.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Krishan v. The State of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Railway servant held public servant under s.2 PCA for offence in 1951 pre-amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: C.A. Montorio v. The State of Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Referred to Ram Krishan; railway servants public servants under PCA pre-1955 amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rai Bahadur Kanwar Raju Nath Ors. v. Promod C. Bhatt, Custodian of Evacuee Property
precedents_cited.relevance: Non-obstante clause inserted ex abundanti cautela to clarify s.137(1).

statutes_cited.name: Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines public servant via IPC s.21; offences of criminal misconduct by public servants.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of public servant; conspiracy; ch.IX offences relating to public servants.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Railways Act, 1890
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems railway servants public servants for ch.IX IPC; bars for other IPC purposes pre-1955 amendment.

outcome.summary: Appeals by special leave dismissed; conviction and sentences under s.120B IPC and s.5(2) r/w s.5(1)(c),(d) PCA confirmed; appellants held public servants under s.2 PCA.

key_quotes.text: Are the appellants S. Gangoli and P. R. Chaudhri hereafter called appellants 1 and 2 respectively public servants under s. 2 of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947?
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Frames the sole issue in the appeal.

key_quotes.text: S. 2 of the Act in substance incorporates in itself the definition of a public servant contained in s. 21 of the Indian Penal Code.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to holding appellants as public servants under PCA.

key_quotes.text: The bar created by sub-s. 4 applies, and is confined, to the purposes of that Code and cannot be extended beyond the said purposes.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects appellants' interpretation of s.137(4) Railways Act.
